title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study Evaluating the Efficacy and Safety of AGB101on Slowing Progression of Mild Cognitive Impairment Due to Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the efficacy of AGB101 on slowing cognitive and functional impairment as measured by changes in the Clinical Dementia Rating-Sum of Boxes (CDR-SB) score as compared with placebo in participants with mild cognitive impairment due to Alzheimer's Disease (MCI due to AD) also known as prodromal AD. Participants will be randomized to receive placebo or AGB101 (220 mg), once daily for 78 weeks. Secondary objectives are to assess the effect of AGB101 compared with placebo on clinical progression as measured by Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) and Functional Activities Questionnaire (FAQ).

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Clinical Dementia Rating-Sum of Boxes (CDR-SB)
measures.description: The CDR-SB is the sum score of 6 domains of cognitive function (memory, orientation, judgment and problem solving, community affairs, home and hobbies, and personal care), with the score of each domain ranging from 0 (no impairment) to 3 (severe impairment). The total possible range is 0 to 18 with higher scores indicating greater impairment.

measures.title: Mini Mental Status Exam (MMSE)
measures.description: The MMSE is the sum score of an 11 item exam designed to assess five components of cognition: orientation, registration, attention and calculation, recall, and language. The total possible range is 0-30, with lower scores indicating greater impairment.

measures.title: Functional Activities Questionnaire (FAQ)
measures.description: The FAQ measures instrumental activities of daily living, such as preparing balanced meals and managing finances. The total possible range is from 0 to 30, with higher scores indicating greater impairment.
measures.populationDescription: Baseline FAQ measure not collected for 7 subjects.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Clinical Dementia Rating Scale - Sum of Boxes (CDR-SB) Score From Baseline
outcomeMeasures.description: CDR-SB scores at baseline were subtracted from CDR-SB scores at week 78 to generate the change score from baseline, with a possible total range of -18 to 18. Positive change scores reflect greater impairment on the CDR-SB at week 78, while negative change scores reflect less impairment on the CDR-SB at week 78.

outcomeMeasures.description: MMSE scores at baseline were subtracted from MMSE scores at week 78 to generate the change score from baseline, with a possible total range of -30 to 30. Positive change scores reflect improved performance on the MMSE at week 78, while negative change scores reflect worsening performance on the MMSE at week 78.

adverseEventsModule.description: Three subjects were randomized and assigned to receive AGB101 but were not treated, lowering the total number of at risk participants treated with AGB101 to 78.

explanation_target: Reason: The investigational product AGB101 is an extended‑release, low‑dose formulation of the small‑molecule anticonvulsant levetiracetam (220 mg) being tested to slow progression of MCI due to Alzheimer’s disease by reducing hippocampal overactivity and related neural hyperexcitability rather than by acting as a symptomatic stimulant only. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Act: The trial is a 78‑week, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study with CDR‑SB as the primary endpoint aiming to slow clinical/cognitive decline in prodromal AD — i.e., a disease‑modifying intent focused on a pathophysiological mechanism (hippocampal overactivity). Trial details and the drug identity/mechanism are described in the HOPE4MCI publications and summaries. citeturn0search1turn0search3turn0search4

Reflect: Given AGB101 is a small molecule (levetiracetam) and the intervention targets a disease‑relevant pathophysiologic process (hippocampal hyperactivity) with the goal of slowing progression, the correct category is 'disease-targeted small molecule'. This classification distinguishes it from (a) biologics (monoclonal antibodies/vaccines) and (b) purely symptomatic cognitive enhancers or neuropsychiatric symptomatic treatments. Supporting reports and trial publications describing normalization of hippocampal activity and the 78‑week CDR‑SB primary outcome support this interpretation. citeturn0search2turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational product AGB101 is an extended‑release, low‑dose (220 mg) formulation of the small‑molecule anticonvulsant levetiracetam being tested to slow progression of MCI due to AD by reducing hippocampal overactivity / neural hyperexcitability — a disease‑relevant synaptic/circuit dysfunction rather than a primary amyloid, tau, inflammatory or vascular target. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — drug: AGB101 (levetiracetam extended‑release, 220 mg); trial: 78‑week, multicenter, randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled with CDR‑SB as the primary endpoint; mechanistic intent: diminish hippocampal overactivity to slow progression. These trial and drug details are described in the HOPE4MCI publications. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Mechanism support: Levetiracetam’s primary molecular binding site is the synaptic vesicle protein SV2A and its actions modulate synaptic vesicle release and neuronal excitability — providing a synaptic/neurophysiological mechanism for reducing hippocampal hyperactivity. citeturn1search8turn1search5

Reflect: Mapping to CADRO — interventions that modulate synaptic function and aim to restore/normalize neuronal network activity fit best under 'M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection'. Levetiracetam does not primarily act on classical neurotransmitter receptors (so D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is less accurate), nor is this a multi‑target biologic, imaging, or non‑therapeutic intervention. Subgroup/exploratory results (e.g., APOE ε4 non‑carrier signals, entorhinal cortex atrophy slowing) are reported but do not change the mechanistic classification. citeturn0search0turn0search4

Output (final classification): M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection — because AGB101 (levetiracetam ER 220 mg) targets synaptic vesicle function/SV2A to reduce hippocampal hyperexcitability and thereby aims to produce neuroprotective / synaptic‑level disease modification. citeturn0search0turn1search8

Web search results used (summary of sources): 1) HOPE4MCI full report (Wiley/Alzheimer's & Dementia TRCI) — randomized 78‑week trial of AGB101 (levetiracetam ER 220 mg) targeting hippocampal overactivity. citeturn0search0 2) PubMed entry for HOPE4MCI (abstract/summary). citeturn0search1 3) Conference/abstracts and trial descriptions describing HOPE4MCI design and hippocampal overactivity rationale. citeturn0search3 4) HOPE4MCI exploratory MRI/biomarker analysis (entorhinal cortex atrophy slowing in APOE ε4 non‑carriers). citeturn0search4 5) Mechanistic literature showing levetiracetam binds SV2A and modulates synaptic vesicle release / network excitability (primary mechanism references/reviews). citeturn1search8turn1search5
